comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
In 2nd May 1904 King Edward visited Waterford. He travelled from Dun Laoghaire, County Dublin via Kilkenny, arriving at Waterford North Station at 12:50 p.m. The station was decorated in crimson and a salute was fired by the HMS Aeolus, which was stationed in the river along three other ships. The King was entertained by the mayor James A. Power at a reception in City Hall.

The Royal party then visited the Waterford Show. The Royal party proceeded to the Waterford South Station to take the 16:05p.m train to Lismore.

Before departing the King knighted the Mayor on the platform. The King then took the train to Lismore where he was greeted by the Duke of Devonshire and other dignitaries.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I thought that could be the Duchess beside the Duke, but now I don't think so. The Duchess was a widow of 60 when they married in 1892: she was 72 by the time of this picture, and looked like this.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The woman between the Duke and King may be Lady Evelyn Mary Petty-FitzMaurice, married to the next Duke, Victor Cavendish.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
From Tuesday, 3 May 1904 in the Irish Times
The King and Queen and Princess Victoria visited Waterford yesterday. Their Majesties were received by the Duke of Devonshire, Lieutenant of the County, and cordially welcomed by a large crowd which had assembled within the precincts of the station. ... The illustrious visitors witnessed the jumping competitions [Spring Show of the Waterford Agricultural Society at S. Patrick's Park], and afterwards left for Lismore Castle, the seat of the Duke of Devonshire. The King conferred a Knighthood upon the Mayor of Waterford, Councillor J.A. Power. Their Majesties arrived at Lismore at half-past five o'clock, for a two days' stay with the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire at Lismore Castle. ... A large house party has been invited to meet Their Majesties.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] That would have been around the time you first unveiled Megazoomification, Here it is, a shot of Rathdrum. Unfortunately, I didn't add all the info there,and I mistyped some of the OCO numbers! Sloppy work. Taking another look at the numbers I listed: OCO_25 No clue,but I think I meant OCO_20, which is Rathfarnham Road crossing the Dodder river. OCO_125 ? docklands in Cork (already ID'd) OCO_121 this is the same Weir on the Dodder that we saw in the snows of 1881 OCO_124 Kilnap Viaduct again. OCO_338 is Sandymount Green, beside the infamous House! OCO_138 ? already ID'd as Blarney (not familiar, I must have meant a different one) probably: OCO_122 is the Dodder again at Beaver Row. OCO_108 is the Nine Arches and today's Dropping Well pub in Milltown

comment._content: I have several postcards that were produced as souvenirs of the royal visit in 1904. This one is by Raphael Tuck A view of the Moss Arch at Lismore Castle This one I just aquired and I think may have been a one off postcard, or at least published in a very small quantity. It shows the Royal party arriving at Waterford Town hall.
